{{Speciesbox | image = Clitocybe Nebularis.JPG | genus = Clitocybe | species = nebularis | authority = ([[August Batsch|Batsch]]), [[Paul Kummer|P.Kumm.]] (1871) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Agaricus nebularis'' Batsch (1789)
''Gymnopus nebularis'' (Batsch) [[Samuel Frederick Gray|Gray]] (1821)
''Omphalia nebularis'' (Batsch) [[Quél.]] (1886)
''Lepista nebularis'' (Fr.) [[Harri Harmaja|Harmaja]] (1974) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Clitocybe nebularis'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape =convex | capShape2=flat | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=bare | sporePrintColor=cream | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | howEdible=caution}} '''''Clitocybe nebularis''''' or '''''Lepista nebularis''''', commonly known as the '''clouded agaric''' or '''cloud funnel''', is an abundant [[Lamella (mycology)|gilled]] [[fungus]] which appears both in [[conifer]]-dominated forests and [[Deciduous|broad-leaved]] woodland in Europe and North America. Appearing in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] from late summer to late autumn, it is [[edible mushroom|edible]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5799~source~gallerychooserresult.asp |title=Archived copy |access-date=2011-11-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000746/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5799~source~gallerychooserresult.asp |archive-date=2016-03-04 |url-status=dead }} It is classified as a category 4 edible mushroom in Russia.{{cite web|url=http://mycoweb.narod.ru/fungi/Clitocybe_nebularis.html|title=Вячеслав Степанов: Грибы Калужской области - Говорушка дымчатая (Clitocybe nebularis )|website=mycoweb.narod.ru}} ==Taxonomy== The species was first described and named as ''Agaricus nebularis'' in 1789 by [[August Johann Georg Karl Batsch]]. It was later placed in the genus ''[[Clitocybe]]'' in 1871 by [[Paul Kummer]] as ''Clitocybe nebularis''. After much consideration by many mycologists, over some years, when it was placed for periods in both ''[[Lepista]]'', and ''[[Gymnopus]]'', it was placed back in ''Clitocybe'' with the [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]], and 1871 creditation it retains today.
''Clitocybe nebularis'' var. ''alba'' Bataille (1911), differs only in having a milk white cap, and is very rare. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the mushroom is 5–25 cm (2–8 in) in diameter, [[wikt:convex|convex]] with an incurved margin, becoming plane to depressed in shape. Cap colours are generally greyish to light brownish-grey, and often covered in a whitish bloom when young. The surface of the cap is usually dry to moist, and radially fibrillose. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is stout, swollen towards the base, becomes hollow with age, and is easily broken. It is usually somewhat lighter than the cap. The flesh is white, and very thick. It has a foul-smelling [[odour]], which has been described as slightly farinaceous to rancid.{{cite web |url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Clitocybe_nebularis.html |title=California Fungi: Clitocybe nebularis |accessdate=2008-01-11 |work= }}
This species is host to the parasitic gilled mushroom ''[[Volvariella surrecta]]'', which is found on older specimens. It may be confused with the poisonous ''[[Entoloma sinuatum]]'' both in Europe or North America, though this species has pink sinuate gills.{{cite book | author = Haas H | year = 1969 | title = The Young Specialist looks at Fungi |pages=128| publisher = Burke | isbn = 0-222-79409-7}} ===Edibility=== It is widely consumed but is 'generally considered better to be avoided'.Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe - Michael Jordan ==Gallery== File:Cluded Agaric pileus.JPG|The Pileus or cap File:Clouded Agaric Gills.JPG|Detail of the gills File:Clouded Agaric underside.JPG|The gills and cut stipe (stalk) File:Hexenring Nebelgrauer Trichterling.JPG|''C. nebularis'' growing in a [[fairy ring]] formation Nevelzwam ( nebularis) (d.j.b.) 02.jpg|Close up of the top of a fully Clitocybe nebularis. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=''Clitocybe nebularis'' (Batsch) P. Kumm. 1871 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=164796 |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2011-10-26}} }} ==External links== {{Commons-inline|Clitocybe nebularis|''Clitocybe nebularis''}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q757125}} [[Category:Clitocybe|nebularis]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1789]] [[Category:Taxa named by August Batsch]]
